awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Translation and Accretion of the Yakutat Microplate and Prince William Terrane, Alaska
awd_abstract_narration:
The North American Cordillera was assembled through the formation, accretion, and translation of a number of terranes and much of this assembly has occurred since the Cretaceous. Since this time, most of the terrane translation was northward due to the relative motion of Pacific plates with North America. Despite decades of investigations on terrane movement and translation much remains unknown about where these terranes originated and how far they traveled before becoming part of the amalgamation of terranes in Alaska. This project brings new analytical techniques to bear on this problem focusing on the Yakutat terrane, which is now colliding with southern Alaska driving the uplift of the Chugach Range. This research tests the idea that the Yakutat terrane originated far to the south in the Pacific Northwest and moved parallel to the continental margin before colliding with southern Alaska. The project would advance desired societal outcomes by participation of students from underrepresented minorities in STEM, increased public scientific literacy and public engagement with STEM through development of brochures for the National Parks and National Forests and development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce through active participation of undergraduate students in research at primarily undergraduate institutions.

The development and translation history of the collage of terranes that make up most of Alaska are debated, including the Chugach and Prince William terranes, and Yakutat terrane. Some scenarios envision a setting for the Chugach and Prince William terranes that was more or less in place, while other scenarios (originally based on paleomagentic data) suggest long transport (>3000 km). The difference in these ideas is profound, but large-scale translation of terranes on strike-slip faults may be a fundamental and underappreciated process in the Cordillera. High-precision and high-volume U/Pb and fission track dating of detrital zircon has focused the lens with which the problem can be examined, and rigorous predictions can be made by making geological comparisons of units along the Cordilleran margin to better understand translation history and total offset. Preliminary data show a number of assumptions about the Chugach-Prince William terrane and Yakutat terrane collision zone need to be revised, including: (1) turbidites of the Yakutat terrane may not be part of the Chugach and Prince William terranes as previously assumed; and (2) the basaltic basement of the Yakutat terrane may have formed in a transtensional environment along the North American margin. The hypothesis tested here is that transport of the Yakutat terrane to Alaska resulted in a truncated margin in the Pacific Northwest, and slip on the Queen Charlotte-Fairweather fault system may have partly accommodated the 1800 km of dextral translation, which may be one of the longest offsets shown by geological relationships on faults in the Cordillera. The analytical approach of this research involves the analysis of detrital zircon using several techniques, some of which are new and innovative. These approaches include: (a) U/Pb of detrital zircon to determine maximum depositional age and provenance, including targeting Precambrian sources; (b) fission track on detrital zircons to provide cooling ages directly related to exhumation, including double dating grains (fission track and U/Pb); (c) Raman spectroscopy on detrital to provide radiation damage dates; (d) Hf isotopes in detrital zircon to provide crustal signature; and (e) core-rim dating to date igneous and metamorphic rims. Determining radiation damage ages on detrital zircon is a new approach that promises to provide deeper insight into detrital studies. Although zircon is central to this effort, student projects that use geochemistry and petrology will focus on better understanding the development of the igneous rocks associated with these terranes.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF UNION COLLEGE IN THE TOWN OF SCHENECTADY IN THE STATE OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The role of large-scale translation along strike-slip faults in shaping the western edge of North America remains highly controversial. The Baja BC hypothesis suggests that the Wrangellia superterrane, a large piece of continental crust in the northern Cordillera, was originally located at the latitude of central Mexico around 100 million years ago and subsequently slid north to Alaska due to oblique motion between Pacific plates and North America. Paleomagnetic data from the Chugach-Prince William (CPW) terrane, seaward of Wrangellia, also suggests that the CPW may have undergone significant northward travel. The goal of this project was to provide geologic ties between the CPW and distinct source terrains along the North American margin to shed light on the timing and extent of terrane translation.

This project furthered our understanding of the tectonic evolution of western North America between 75 and 55 million years ago (Ma) by providing ties to the source rocks of the CPW terranes. By integrating geochronology and isotopic analyses, we determined the age of these rocks, where they formed, and how they may have slid north to Alaska along the margin of North America. To study these rocks, we used radiometric dating and isotopic analysis  (U/Pb and Lu/Hf) of the mineral zircon to constrain the age of deposition and provenance (source region) of the sandstones, to date igneous rocks, and evaluate crustal age.

The CPW terrane consists of three elements. The oldest rocks are arc-related clastic deposits, including the mid-Cretaceous McHugh Complex and the "Old" Sitka Graywacke, that formed near Wrangellia and the associated Peninsular arc. The Campanian to Paleocene (75-58 Ma) Valdez Group and equivalent units, are characterized by sediment derived from a juvenile volcanic arc built on an older metaplutonic basement, with detrital zircon ages mainly between 70-75 Ma, which requires a batholithic source that is not directly adjacent to this belt. A candidate is the Sierra Madre Occidental in Mexico, which is consistent with the age and crustal composition, unlike other candidate batholiths in the Cordillera. If correct, this would suggest sediment and/or tectonic transport of >3000 km.  The Paleocene to Eocene (60-55 Ma) Orca Group, records erosion from the underlying Valdez Group, and also the Coast Plutonic Complex in British Columbia.  An important stratigraphic change at c. 58-60 Ma is recorded in the Valdez to Orca transition, and the occurrence of interbedded volcanic rocks in the Orca Group indicate crustal extension at ~57 Ma.

The Yakutat Group, part of a composite terrane currently colliding with the North American margin, is age correlative to the Valdez Group, but we now recognize it as a distinct and unrelated unit. The Yakutat Group mélange and stratified sedimentary sequences, are dominated by arkosic sandstones and conglomerates deposited between Campanian and Paleocene time, and they have detrital zircon ages and isotopic signatures identical to the Nanaimo Group and Western Mélange Belt in the Pacific Northwest.  These rocks were probably contiguous prior to ~50 Ma.  All of these units are similar to potential source rocks in the Mojave region of California, and this may suggest that the Yakutat terrane was originally part of southern Wrangellia before being transported from California northward during Paleocene and Eocene time.

The Sanak-Baranof belt (SBB) plutons intrude both the CPW and Yakutat terranes along the entire belt. These near-trench plutons formed between 63 and 48 Ma, with older plutons to the west (Sanak Island) and younger ones to the east (Baranof Island). In the western belt the plutons show an eastward age progression with increasingly evolved isotopic signatures, while the eastern belt has mantle-derived signatures in younger plutons. These patterns reflect significant changes in plate dynamics or mantle configuration by ~57-55 Ma.

Broader impacts of this work include advancing public education, natural resource management, and hazard assessment in southern Alaska.  This includes National Parks (Kenai Fjords, Wrangell-St. Elias, and Glacier Bay) and National Forests (Chugach and Tongass) that are underlain by rocks of the CPW. By improving the understanding of the age, origin, and tectonic history of these rocks, this research will enhance educational programs and visitor experiences, through a better understanding of the tectonic forces that shaped the region. It also informs resource assessments for oil, gas, and minerals while identifying potential geological hazards along faults. Additionally, this work supports geoscience education and workforce development by involving undergraduate students in hands-on research, such as geochronology, petrology, and tectonic analysis, providing them with technical skills for careers in the geosciences and promoting critical thinking and collaboration across institutions.

CPW and Yakutat rocks show evidence of transport over 3000 km, with potential ties to source regions in the Sierra Madre Occidental and Mojave regions. This research advances our understanding of tectonic history, resource assessments, and hazard planning while enhancing public education and training students in geoscience research.


 

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2024
Modified by: John I Garver
